Key Laboratory of Superlight Materials and Surface Technology Ministry of Education College of Materials Science and Chemical Engineering Harbin Engineering University Harbin Heilongjiang 150001 China Due to the unique structure of perovskite materials, their capacitance can be improved by introducing oxygen vacancy. In this paper, the LaMnO3- δ material containing oxygen vacancy was synthesized by molten salt method in KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 melt. The La–Mn–O crystal grows gradually in molten salt with the increase of temperature. It was confirmed that LaMnO3- δ with perovskite structure and incomplete oxygen content were synthesized by molten salt method and presented a three-dimensional shape. LaMnO3- δ stores energy by redox reaction and adsorption of OH− in electrolyte simultaneously. In comparison with the stoichiometric LaMnO3 prepared by the sol–gel method, LaMnO3- δ prepared by molten salt method proffered higher capacitance and better performance. The galvanostatic charge–discharge curve showed specific capacitance of 973.5 F/g under current density of 1 A/g in 6 M KOH. The capacitance of LaMnO3- δ was 82.7% under condition of 5 A/g compared with the capacitance at the current of 1A/g, and the specific capacitances of 648.0 and 310.0 F/g were obtained after 2000 and 5000 cycles of galvanostatic charging–discharging, respectively. Molten salt synthesis method is relatively simple and suitable for industrial scale, presenting a promising prospect in the synthesis of perovskite oxide materials. Graphical abstract LaMnO3- δ containing oxygen vacancies was synthesized in KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 salt at 300 °C in air condition for energy storage. Image, graphical abstract Keywords LaMnO3- δ Perovskite oxide KNO3–NaNO3–NaNO2 melt Supercapacitor Molten salt synthesis 1 Introduction A new generation of energy storage equipment is being developed and chosen as alternative energy sources to the traditional fossil materials due to the reduction of non-renewable fossil fuel resources and the increasing demand for environmental protection [1]. Among various energy storage devices, supercapacitor has received a lot of attention in recent few decades [2,3]. Based on the different energy storage mechanisms, supercapacitor can be sorted into two categories: one is electrical double layer capacitance caused by pure electrostatic attraction at the electrode/electrolyte interface. The second one is the Faraday pseudocapacitance. Because of the highly reversible adsorption, desorption and redox chemical reactions, capacitance related to the electrode charging potential is obtained [4]. Among traditional pseudocapacitor materials, MnO2, NiO, SnO2 and V2O5 store energy by rapid redox reaction [5–8]. In recent years, several novel capacitive materials containing oxygen vacancies were synthesized by constructing lattice vacancy in traditional pseudo-capacitor materials. The capacitance can be generated by adsorption and desorption of ions in the electrolyte through oxygen vacancy on the surface of electrode along with redox reactions [9]. Such electrode material is of great significance in the selection of functional materials for portable equipment due to its high volume specific capacitance [10]. Oxygen-poor state MoO3- x leads to a larger layer spacing compared to the fully oxidized MoO3. This phenomenon is ascribed to the oxygen vacancy, which promotes faster charge storage kinetics and preserves the α-MoO3 structure during insertion and removal of Li ions [11]. Lin et al. [12] prepared monodisperse/polydisperse TiO2 precursor submicrospheres by sol–gel method through mixing the precursor with LiOH and sucrose to form Li4Ti5O12- x /C containing oxygen vacancy in argon atmosphere at 800 °C as a cathode material for lithium-ion batteries. The conductivity of Li4Ti5O12− x /C particles and Li+ ion diffusion were significantly higher than those of Li4Ti5O12 with complete stoichiometric ratio. The potential importance of introducing oxygen vacancy to transition metal oxides to improve the charge storage kinetics of active redox substances was extensively emphasized [13]. In recent years, perovskite-type metal oxides as supercapacitor materials have been presented in several reports [14,15]. Perovskite oxides with oxygen vacancy have become promising electrode materials. It was found that oxygen intercalation has a significant influence on layered perovskite nanoparticles as supercapacitor electrodes. Mefford et al. [16] prepared LaMnO3±0.09 by inverse hydrolysis reverse method, and found that the specific capacitance of LaMnO3.09 was higher than LaMnO2.91 in alkaline solution. They further explained that phenomenon by using alkaline solution of different anion concentrations and neutral electrolytes. In addition to traditional perovskite oxides, the synthesis of double perovskite material with oxygen vacancy has also been reported [17]. The PrBaMn2O6− δ was synthesized by ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid-anhydrous citric acid (EDTA-CA) complexing approach, which can reach a maximum gravimetric capacitance of 1034.8 F/g in 6 M KOH solution with a small specific surface area of only 7.83 m2/g [18]. At present, various methods for synthesizing, such as sol–gel, reverse hydrolysis, complexation method combined with argon or hydrogen sintering have been reported [19,20]. However, those methods require multi-step reactions for production of perovskite oxygen vacancy materials. Therefore, they are not easily applicable for large-scale industry. Herein, a new molten salt method is proposed for synthesizing the perovskite materials containing oxygen vacancy molten salt. KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 (53:7:40 wt%) system with the melting point range of 140 °C–155 °C was selected as molten salt media in which perovskite oxide was synthesized. Moreover, reaction precursor can sink at the bottom of crucible because of its small density and viscosity. The property of oxidation and the low melting point for our system facilitates reaction precursor to sink at the bottom of crucible, allowing the reaction to proceed without the need to contact with a large amount of air [21]. One advantage of molten salt method is that the sealing devices are not required for setting up the experimental conditions. As a result, huge amounts of perovskite materials can be simply produced [22,23]. For supercapacitor material, the energy can be stored by both redox reaction and vacancy adsorption of OH− ions in an alkaline electrolyte. Consequently, high capacitance can be obtained without using materials of high specific surface area. In this study, perovskite oxide LaMnO3- δ as a supercapacitor material was synthesized by the molten salt method. The morphology and oxygen vacancy of LaMnO3- δ were determined by various characterization methods. The electrochemical properties were characterized by several electrochemical measurements. The specific capacitance of the first gravimetric discharge cycle can reach 973.6 F/g at current density of 1 A/g in 6 M KOH. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of LaMnO3-δ and LaMnO3 material Fig. 1 shows the schematic diagram of the preparation process of LaMnO3- δ using molten salt method. All the chemicals were dried in advance under vacuum conditions at 120 °C. The dried manganese chloride (MnCl2) and lanthanum chloride (LaCl3) with an equal molar ratio was placed in a mortar and grounded to a uniform mixing. An alumina crucible containing 30 g mixed salt KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 (53:7:40 wt%) was put in an open electric resistance furnace at 300 °C as maximum temperature with heating rate 10 °C/min. The mixed salt reached the melting point in about 15 min. Then, the ground sample (MnCl2 and LaCl3) was added to the molten salt through a fine corundum tube, and the preliminary product was obtained in air atmosphere at the set temperature for 3 h. After the chemical reaction, the sample in the corundum crucible was a black liquid. The product was then allowed to cool down to room temperature and washed with distilled water under vigorous magnetic stirring. The washing process was repeated several times until the pH value of the filtration liquid became around 7. Finally, crystallized black solid La–Mn–O was obtained after drying in a 100 °C vacuum oven for 10 h. The experimental processes at 200 °C and 400 °C were the same as the above, except for the final set temperature. The LaMnO3 was prepared by the sol–gel method as reported in Ref. [14]. 2.2 Material characterization The crystal structures of the samples were studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 type, Germany) in the range of 20°–90° with filtered Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy experiments were performed using the surface analysis system (XPS, Thermofisher Escalab Xi+). Al K α radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV) from a monochromatic X-ray source and a 500-µm light spot size was used. The valence spectrums were recorded at the pass energy of 20 eV with a step of 0.05 eV. The binding energy of other elements in the spectrum is corrected by the difference between the measured value of the carbon peak and the reference value (284.8 eV) as the charge-electric correction value. The surface morphologies of the samples were characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Apreo S LoVac) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100 model). The compositions of elements coupled with SEM were analyzed by energy spectrometer-electron backscattering diffractometer (EDS, Octane Elect Super+Hikari Plus) for point and surface of samples. 2.3 Preparation and electrochemical behavior measurement of LaMnO3-δ electrode A mixture of the active materials (prepared LaMnO3- δ , 75 wt%), conductive agent (Super-P, 15 wt%), and binder (PTFE, 10 wt%) were placed in a small beaker and well distributed by magnetic stirring. After that, the slurry was treated with nickel foam after cleaning the foam nickel (4 × 1 cm2) ultrasonically in ethanol and deionized water for 30 min, and the areal density of the slurry was about 3 mg/cm2. The electrodes used in our system are, dried nickel electrode coated with electrode material (working electrode), Ag/AgCl electrode filled with saturated KCl (reference electrode), and carbon rod electrode as counter electrode, in addition to 6 M KOH solution as an electrolyte. The electrochemical performances of CV (cyclic voltammetry) were investigated by CHI760B electrochemical workstation (Shanghai). The galvanostatic charging–discharging (GCD) tests and EIS (electrochemical impedance spectroscopy) were conducted using AUTOLAB PGSTAT 302 N workstation. The equivalent circuits were fitted by Nova (1.8.14) software. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and morphological analysis Fig. 2 shows the thermogravimetric (TG) curve of KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 (53:7:40 wt%) mixture in air condition at 30 °C–800 °C. The obtained result reveals that the nitrate molten salt is very stable in air conditions within the range of 200 °C–400 °C, and the decomposition temperature of the mixed salt starts at 630 °C. Therefore, the ternary mixed nitrate molten salt can exist stably in air at 200 °C–400 °C. To understand the growth process of La–Mn–O compounds in KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 melt, three kinds of La–Mn–O powders were prepared at 200, 300 and 400 °C in KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 melt. The XRD patterns and the SEM images of the synthesized products are shown in Fig. 3 . As shown in Fig. 3(a, b), the average particle size of the product prepared at 200 °C is 20–40 nm. It is observed that the solid particles are relatively dispersed without agglomeration. However, there are many miscellaneous peaks in XRD pattern, and the matching single product is not detected. On the other hand, the particle size of the product prepared at 300 °C is about 0.5–1 µm, and the agglomeration phenomenon is observed as shown in Fig. 3(c and d). The position and intensities of the XRD peaks are in a good agreement with the characteristic peaks of La0.96MnO2.94 (PDF#89-0683). The characteristic peaks at 22.7°, 32.5°, 40°, 46.5°, 58°, 68° and 77° represent (101), (121), (220), (202), (123), (242) and (323) crystal planes, respectively, indicating that incomplete stoichiometric ratio LaMnO3- δ has been successfully prepared [24]. Moreover, there are barely miscellaneous peaks in the XRD pattern and crystal interface can be seen clearly, revealing that the product prepared by molten salt system has high purity with a clear crystal interface. When the temperature increase to 400 °C, the particle size grows to 2–5 µm with irregular morphology compared with LaMnO3- δ prepared at 300 °C, and the agglomeration phenomenon disappear as can be seen from Fig. 3(e). Compared with the XRD standard diffraction card of La0.96MnO3.15, the position of diffraction peak is basically the same as shown in Fig. 3(f). The La–Mn–O products prepared at different temperatures show similar polyhedral structures. Therefore, the temperature of the reaction does not significantly affect the morphology of La–Mn–O crystals in KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 melt. In molten salt system, crystal of the particles grows up through the mass transfer process in liquid phase [25]. The precursors MnCl2 and LaCl3 have certain solubility in KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 ternary molten salt, therefore the solute phase grows at a relatively lower temperature than its melting point [26]. Raw materials MnCl2 and LaCl3 were dissolved in molten KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2. The structure of La3+ is stable and its valence is hard to change. While, the existence of oxygen in the molten salt aids oxidizing Mn2+ to form Mn3+ and Mn4+. At 200 °C, there are no aggregates observed for the precursor particles dissolved in molten salt. While by increasing the temperature to 300 °C, the dispersed ions of the precursor begin to aggregate, and the La–Mn–O nucleus were formed and grown. Therefore, the product is partially aggregated. With the growth of the nucleus, the oxygen dissolved in the molten salt is not adequate to form complete stoichiometric compound with the La and Mn precursors, leading to the formation of oxygen vacancy. By increasing the temperature to reach 400 °C, the size of La–Mn–O crystals grew from nano-sized to the micron-sized and detached from the aggregated crystal to form more dispersed and unique particles. At 400 °C, NaNO2 in melt decomposed into O2 and NO, leading to the replenishment of oxygen vacancy. The strong oxidation of NO could even lead to the formation of stoichiometric ratio La–Mn–O. The particle size of the crystal is inversely proportional to the width of XRD diffraction peak. Hence, the obtained results from Fig. 3 declare that the change of crystal particle size is in good agreement with the data from XRD measurements. The surface state of the material was studied by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to characterize both the valence and content of the elements in the perovskite oxide. Based on the results of XPS spectra and fitting shown in Fig. 4 , La 3d region shows well separated spin-orbit components, and each spin-orbit component is further split by multiplet splitting. The peaks at 833.6 and 838.0 eV belong to the split peak of La 3d 5/2 and the peaks appearing at binding energy 850.4 and 854.8 eV are due to La 3d 3/2 as illustrated in Fig. 4(a). In addition, the doublet separation of the La 3d 5/2 and La 3d 3/2 is 16.8 eV, revealing presence of La3+ ions [14]. Generally, according to results in Fig. 4(b), the manganese exists as Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ in manganese oxides. The peaks located at 640.7, 641.9, and 643.5 eV correspond to Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+, respectively. Moreover, a satellite feature appears at around 647.0 eV suggesting existence of Mn2+, while the identifiable shape at the top of the Mn 2p3/2 peak implies the formation of Mn4+ [27]. The proportion of Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+ was 0.30/0.47/0.23. Obviously, Mn3+ is the dominant species, and the content of Mn2+ is higher than that of Mn4+. Fig. 4(c) displays the spectrum of O 1 s, in which, the peak of 529.1 eV represents lattice oxygen, and the peak at 531.2 eV is the peak of adsorbed oxygen in air caused by environment and vacancy oxygen [14]. In order to prove the existence of vacancy oxygen, the LaMnO3 materials with complete stoichiometric ratio were prepared by traditional sol–gel method and investigated by XPS. Fig. 4(d, e) shows XPS spectra of Mn 2p and O 1 s for LaMnO3 and LaMnO3- δ . The raw curves were basically covered by the fitting curves. The binding energy of Mn 2p and O 1 s in the LaMnO3- δ synthesized by molten salt method moves 0.2 and 0.5 eV in the direction of increase. The formation of adjacent oxygen vacancies presents relatively high electron attraction and leads to higher binding energy [28]. The surface oxygen content of Oab/Ola in LaMnO3 (0.97) is lower than that in LaMnO3- δ (1.14) because of the oxygen vacancies. The crystal structure and element distribution of LaMnO3- δ were characterized by TEM and SEM-EDS as shown in Fig. 5 . The LaMnO3- δ synthesized by the molten salt method basically exhibits a three-dimensional cube shape with a distinct boundary after magnifying 10,000 times (Fig. 5a and b). The regular lattice fringes demonstrate a high degree of crystallization in Fig. 5(c). The width of lattice fringes in HRTEM is 0.28 nm, corresponding to (121) crystal plane of LaMnO3- δ . The EDS spectrum of the selected area in Fig. 6 (a) was recorded for further investigation. Fig. 6(b–e) reveals the existence of La, Mn, O and Cl in the synthesized material. The presence of small amount of Cl element may be due to the raw materials, MnCl2 and LaCl3. Fig. 6(f) shows that the atomic ratio of La/Mn is almost 1:1, at the meanwhile, the atomic ratio of oxygen to lanthanum or manganese is less than three on the basis of ZAF quantitative correction method. It is also confirmed that oxygen-deficient LaMnO3- δ was successfully synthesized by molten salt method. 3.2 Electrochemical characterization LaMnO3- δ oxide was studied as active material in the system of 6 M KOH solution in order to evaluate its potential application as an oxygen-negative intercalated supercapacitor electrode. The electrochemical test results are shown in Fig. 7 . The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were performed in the potential range of 0–0.5 V (all the potentials in this study were referred to Ag/AgCl). The electrochemical reaction of LaMnO3- δ can be obtained from the CV curves at scan rates of 2 mV/s as shown in Fig. 7(a). Two peaks at 0.30 and 0.23 V correspond to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ and Mn3+ to Mn2+, respectively. While the oxidation peaks located at 0.29 and 0.38 V are due to the oxidation of Mn2+ to Mn3+ and Mn3+ to Mn4+. This result shows that LaMnO3- δ includes two steps of redox reaction in 6 M KOH under the investigated potential range. As the sweep speed increased, the CV curve shape did not change. The potential movements corresponding to the peak currents are ascribed to the polarization of the electrode. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the specific capacitances of LaMnO3- δ are 973.6, 863.5, 805.5, and 306 F/g at current densities of 1, 2, 5, and 10 A/g, respectively, confirming their reversible charge storage capability and the ability of withstanding large current density. The capacitance of LaMnO3- δ keeps constant at 82.7% under the condition of 5 A/g compared with the capacitance at the current density of 1 A/g, revealing a good rate performance. Fig. 7(c) presents the galvanostatic charging and discharging curve of LaMnO3. The specific capacitances 259.4, 216.1 and 123 F/g, at current densities of 1, 2 and 10 A/g, are much lower than those of LaMnO3- δ under the same investigated conditions. The electrode material was charged and discharged for 5000 times at applied current density of 1 A/g. The actual cycle discharge capacitance and coulomb efficiency are shown in Fig. 7(d). At 2000 cycle, the discharge specific capacitance is 648 F/g. However, more than 2000 cycles, the capacity starts to drop rapidly and only 310 F/g is left after 5000 cycles. The phenomena possibly due to the large particle size of the as-synthesized cube material and the change of the crystal structure after multiple charging and discharging, resulting in a decrease in capacity. Moreover, it is well known that La–Mn–O is an excellent catalyst for water oxidation, and oxygen vacancy can further improve the water oxidation [29]. The inset of Fig. 7(a) clearly shows occurrence of oxygen evolution near the positive scan limit. The oxygen evolution also accounts for the narrow potential range and the capacitance decay as in Fig. 7(d). In future research, precursor materials with smaller particle size or other molten salt systems to synthesize smaller particles should be applied to improve their cycling properties. Other electrolytes that are not easy to decompose can also be considered. Though the Coulomb efficiency has been maintained above 98%. The EIS spectrum is composed of a straight line in the low frequency region and a semicircle of the high frequency region. The slope of the former is related to the capacitance characteristics, while the diameter of the half circle represents the charge transfer resistor in the latter [30]. The EIS spectra before and after 5000 charge–discharge cycles were collected (Fig. 7e), and the equivalent circuits fitting were carried out by Nova software (Fig. 7f and g), and the existing parameters were quantitatively processed. Initially, the small resistance of the electrode material and the electrolyte itself (R s) was 1.69 Ω. There are two time-constants during the electrochemical reaction. The first one is related to the surface state of the electrode and the redox reaction at high frequency, and the second corresponds to the charge transfer process at low frequency. The R ct2 of 245 mΩ at the initial state easily facilities the electrode reaction for LaMnO3- δ . The Warburg impedance is very small, revealing the rapid ion transfer process. The value of R s increased by 0.1 Ω after 5000 charge–discharge cycles, indicating that the conductivity of the material is hardly changed. However, the value of R ct1 increased by 365 mΩ, indicating an increase in the surface roughness of the electrode after cyclic test which may be due to the decomposition of electrode materials during the charge and discharge progress. The increase in R ct2 from 245 to 528 mΩ implies the increased difficulty of charge transfer. The weakness of capacitance behavior is ascribed to the high value of Warburg impedance and the small slope of straight line. After circulation, the charge transfer and mass transfer processes of LaMnO3- δ became more difficult, as a result, the capacity decay in the cycle process occurred [31]. The comparison of our work with previous similar works is shown in Table 1 . The capacitance of LaMnO3- δ synthetized by molten salt method is higher than that of La0.7Sr0.3CoO3- δ (LSC)@MnO2 synthesized by controlled electrospinning combined with hydrothermal synthesis within 2000 GCD cycles [32]. Even after 5000 cycles, the capacitance of LaMnO3- δ presents higher capacitance than that of La0.5Ca0.5MnO3 synthetized by improved sol–gel method [33], and LaMnO3–SiO2 synthetized by cyclohexene-assisted impregnation method [34]. Although the capacitance of LaMnO3- δ is lower than that of PrBaMn2O6- δ synthesized by EDTA-CA method [18], but the experimental steps in this study are less with high one-off yield. In addition, the vacuum condition is not necessary and the reaction can be achieved in the air condition. Therefore, the preparation of LaMnO3- δ in molten salt is a suitable method for industrial scale because of its simple operation, low cost and high product conversion rate when compared with the traditional approaches for preparation of perovskite oxide containing oxygen vacancy. The oxygen vacancy materials synthesized by this method are not only limited to supercapacitors, but also can be used in catalysis, solar cells and many other applications [35–37]. However, the products synthesized by molten salt method possess large particle size and can easily agglomeration behavior. In the future research, the reaction conditions of molten salt will be optimized in order to obtain better quality with efficient properties. Combined with the results of a variety of electrochemical measurements above, the reaction mechanism of oxygen vacancy perovskite oxide in alkaline electrolyte is shown in Fig. 8 . The reaction is described as the following equations: (1) La(Mn2 δ 2+,Mn(1 – 2 δ ) 3+)O3− δ  + 2δOH− ↔ LaMn3+O3 + 2δe− + δH2O (2) LaMn3+O3 + 2δOH− ↔ La(Mn2 δ 4+,Mn(1 − 2 δ ) 3+)O3+ δ  + 2δe− + δH2O The LaMnO3- δ synthesized by the molten salt method includes three valence states of manganese. Two pairs of redox reactions can occur in the potential range of 0–0.5 V. The oxygen vacancy can provide ion transport channel. While the quick redox reactions produce pseudo-capacitance, the oxygen vacancies can also adsorb OH− in the alkaline electrolyte. Therefore, the prepared perovskite oxide has a large mass-specific capacitance. Moreover, the large radius of La3+ can maintain the perovskite structure of the product, which is beneficial to keep the capacity during cyclic charge and discharge processes [29]. 4 Conclusions In summary, highly pure perovskite oxides LaMnO3- δ containing oxygen vacancy was synthesized by molten salt method in KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 (53:7:40 wt%) melt at 300 °C. After magnifying 1000 times, the cubic particles with size of 0.5–1 µm were clearly observed. Electric charges can be stored in two ways resulting in a higher capacitance compared with the LaMnO3 of the complete stoichiometric ratio in alkaline electrolyte. Under the current density of 1 A/g, the specific capacitance of LaMnO3- δ was 973.6 F/g. After 2000 and 5000 cycles, the discharge specific capacitances were 648.0 and 310.0 F/g, respectively. The molten salt method is simple to operate, suitable for mass production, and environment-friendly, providing a new idea for the synthesis of oxygen vacancy perovskite electrode materials in the future. coredata.dc:description: Due to the unique structure of perovskite materials, their capacitance can be improved by introducing oxygen vacancy. In this paper, the LaMnO3- δ material containing oxygen vacancy was synthesized by molten salt method in KNO3 NaNO3 NaNO2 melt. The La–Mn–O crystal grows gradually in molten salt with the increase of temperature. It was confirmed that LaMnO3- δ with perovskite structure and incomplete oxygen content were synthesized by molten salt method and presented a three-dimensional shape. LaMnO3- δ stores energy by redox reaction and adsorption of OH− in electrolyte simultaneously. In comparison with the stoichiometric LaMnO3 prepared by the sol–gel method, LaMnO3- δ prepared by molten salt method proffered higher capacitance and better performance. The galvanostatic charge–discharge curve showed specific capacitance of 973.5 F/g under current density of 1 A/g in 6 M KOH. The capacitance of LaMnO3- δ was 82.7% under condition of 5 A/g compared with the capacitance at the current of 1A/g, and the specific capacitances of 648.0 and 310.0 F/g were obtained after 2000 and 5000 cycles of galvanostatic charging–discharging, respectively. Molten salt synthesis method is relatively simple and suitable for industrial scale, presenting a promising prospect in the synthesis of perovskite oxide materials.
coredata.prism:publisher: Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V. and Science Press.
coredata.dc:title: Molten salt synthesis and supercapacitor properties of oxygen-vacancy LaMnO3− δ
coredata.prism:copyright: © 2019 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V. and Science Press. All rights reserved.
